description: Set the deterministic mode. When a calculation is performed in parallel over multiple CPUs or cores, the order in which specific computations occur can and will change. This can cause roundoff errors to accumulate differently. Deterministic mode sacrifices efficiency and memory to force the parallel computation to result in the same answer every time, regardless of the number of CPUs it is performed on or their relative speed. All results are equally valid as they are within the range of finite-precision floating point error, but deterministic mode ensures repeatability. Deterministic mode is reset to the default setting whenever a 'model new' command is given.

keywords.name: default
keywords.description: Set the default deterministic mode setting to b. This default is used when 'model new' is given. Can also be changed via 'Determinism by default' checkbox in Options Dialog

notes: On installation (prior to user changes), default determinism is ON
'model new' resets deterministic mode to the default setting

examples.description: Enable deterministic mode for current model (results repeatable)
Disable deterministic mode - faster but non-repeatable results
Set default deterministic mode to ON (affects future 'model new')
Set default deterministic mode to OFF

examples.command:
model new
; determinism is reset to default here
model deterministic on
examples.description: After model new, explicitly enable determinism

examples.command:
model deterministic off
; Run production simulation faster
model cycle 100000
examples.description: Disable determinism for faster production runs (not for archival)

examples.command:
model deterministic on
; Run for support/debugging with repeatability
model cycle 10000
model save 'debug_state.sav'
examples.description: Enable determinism for debugging/support - ensures repeatable results

python_sdk_alternative.workaround: itasca.command('model deterministic on') or itasca.command('model deterministic off') - Python SDK does not provide direct deterministic control
